Giant Kangaroos That Lived During the Ice Age May Have Hopped—Despite Weighing Up to 550 Pounds
The extinct animals may have bounced from scary situations, such as coming face-to-face with hungry predators
For many people, thinking of Ice Age animals evokes images of woolly mammoths, saber-toothed tigers and giant sloths. But in prehistoric Australia, giant kangaroos also roamed the land. What’s more, these extinct behemoths may have hopped—despite their massive weights, according to a study published January 22 in the journal Scientific Reports.
“Giant kangaroos, their motion has been the subject of debate for a little bit now because they are so much larger than anything we have today,” Megan Jones, a mammal evolution researcher at the University of Manchester in England, tells ABC News’ Julia Jacobo.
Previous research indicated that kangaroos weighing more than about 350 pounds would rupture their ankle tendons if they tried to hop. The largest of the Ice Age kangaroos, Procoptodon goliah, which went extinct around 40,000 years ago, may have weighed up to a whopping 550 pounds.
Did you know? Drivers of extinction
Some past research indicated that ancient humans, rather than climate change, may have hunted giant kangaroos into extinction. But a study published last fall suggests that Indigenous Australians simply hunted the creatures’ fossils, not the animals themselves, and didn’t drive their disappearance.
But Jones and her colleagues noticed that past studies had primarily scaled up today’s kangaroos, which weigh up to about 200 pounds, to study the ancient ones—and may have overlooked important anatomical differences in the process.
So, the researchers examined hindlimb bones from a mixture of modern and extinct kangaroos and related animals, measuring a total of 139 modern specimens and 40 fossils representing 63 species. The team focused on two possible factors that could limit the ancient giants’ ability to bounce: bone strength and tendon size.
Extinct kangaroos had shorter, thicker foot bones that could handle intense landing forces, the researchers found, as well as sufficiently wide bones in their heels for thick ankle tendons—way thicker than the ankle tendons of kangaroos today. In other words, the giant animals’ anatomical features suggest that they could have hopped.
Still, “whether they did hop is a different question,” Jones tells New Scientist’s Chris Simms.
If they did, hopping likely wouldn’t have been their only means of travel. The thicker tendons probably lent themselves to sudden, brief hopping stints rather than long, bounding journeys, study co-author Katrina Jones, a comparative anatomist at the University of Bristol in England, says in a statement. The kangaroos probably hopped to traverse rough terrain or escape from predators, such as the marsupial lions of the Thylacoleo genus, the authors write in the paper.
Furthermore, the giant kangaroos may have moved in many different ways, the team found. Some seemed to have walked on four limbs, while others traveled upright on two legs, hinting that hopping may have been one of several forms of locomotion for these creatures.
More broadly, the new study might provide clues about why giant kangaroos disappeared, Gilbert Price, a vertebrate paleoecologist at the University of Queensland in Australia who was not involved in the study, tells the Guardian’s Nicola Davis.
“If you want to understand why these animals went extinct, you first have to understand what they were actually like,” he tells the outlet. “Bringing the focus back to their biology and ecology isn’t just extra detail but is central to understanding what happened.”

articles.title: 8 Incredible Directors Never Nominated for an Oscar
articles.author: Suhaib Adeel
articles.excerpt: Most of the highly acclaimed directors in Hollywood have at least one Oscar nomination, but there have been exceptions. Once you start digging, you realize some of the most influential filmmakers,...
articles.content:
Most of the highly acclaimed directors in Hollywood have at least one Oscar nomination, but there have been exceptions. Once you start digging, you realize some of the most influential filmmakers, some of whom have defined and redefined genres, somehow slipped past the Academy entirely.
And these arenât even directors with only a few good movies to their names; some of these have had many acclaimed movies within their careers that have spanned decades. These are filmmakers whose movies have been studied in-depth and whose works have been copied, borrowed, or remixed by many others.Â
Here are eight great directors who never received an Oscar nomination, even though their fingerprint is all over modern and retro cinema.
- Sergio Leone
- John Carpenter
- Park Chan-wook
- David Cronenberg
- Brian De Palma
- Wong Kar-wai
- BÃ©la Tarr
- Claire Denis
Sergio Leone
Sergio Leone had a very specific kind of patience. He didnât rush scenes, and didnât outright explain characters much. His westerns, especially The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, along with its two predecessors, completely rewired the genre and made his name synonymous with it. And who can forget his extreme close-up shots?Â
Still, he didnât receive any Oscar nominations for his films. He did eventually receive an Honorary Oscar in 2003, but that was several decades after his most influential work, which was literally genre-defining.Â
John Carpenter
John Carpenterâs movies have always seemed more interested in atmosphere than explanation, and thatâs refreshing. Halloween alone made a big impact in the horror genre, and there was also The Thing. A lot of people donât know that he also wrote and composed much of the music for his films.Â
Despite his massive influence on the sci-fi and horror genres, Carpenter never received an Oscar nomination.
Park Chan-wook
Park Chan-wookâs stories are usually unsettling. His films might seem elegant on the surface, or at first, but are uncomfortable underneath, which is a tricky balance to pull off consistently.Â
Oldboy is the obvious starting point, but Lady Vengeance deserves a lot of praise too. Heâs remained very consistent with his work, even when doing TV like with 2024âs The Sympathizer, and most recently, No Other Choice.Â
Despite international acclaim, Park has not received an Oscar nomination as a director yet.Â No Other Choice was shut out of this yearâs Oscars completely, making it one of the most egregious snubs.
David Cronenberg
If thereâs one director who truly understands the intersection of technology and human bodies, itâs David Cronenberg. Cronenberg is yet another director who has defined a subgenre, this time being body horror. His movies make people uncomfortable, which seems to be the point.
Even after five decades of directing, he continues to make deeply unsettling movies that are very good, most recently with The Shrouds.Â
The Academy has yet to nominate him for a movie, though perhaps thatâs not too surprising, considering Cronenbergâs films sit far outside the Academyâs traditional comfort zone.Â
Brian De Palma
Brian De Palma is an expert in multiple genres. Carrie remains one of the most brutal horror films, and Blow Out is a paranoid masterpiece. Then thereâs Scarface and The Untouchables, which are both great gangster movies.Â
While actors in his films have won an Oscar (Sean Connery for The Untouchables), the man behind the camera hasnât. He hasnât even won an honorary Oscar, which feels like a disservice to one of the architects of the New Hollywood era.
Wong Kar-wai
The plots in the movies by Wong Kar-wai are usually simple, but the greater human feelings are not. Heâs less interested in where a story goes and more interested in how it lingers.Â
Heâs also known for the improvisation in his movies, and letting the chemistry of his actors guide the movie rather than strict plot points.Â In the Mood for Love is his most famous work, and for good reason. The use of music, slow motion, and color in this movie is very captivating.
The Academy somehow never nominated him as a director, which is a huge mistake.
BÃ©la Tarr
The late BÃ©la Tarr didnât make movies for everyone. You need time and patience for them, but the experiences are so rewarding. His storytelling was deliberately slow, almost stubbornlyâa true antithesis of the modern blockbuster.Â
SÃ¡tÃ¡ntangÃ³ is legendary for its length of seven hours, but the runtime isnât a gimmick. You can feel the weight of repetition and despair in a way that you wouldnât with a shorter film. His long takes (often more than 10 minutes) and black-and-white imagery felt hypnotic in a way you donât see often.Â Â
The Academy never nominated Tarr, but his work was definitely Oscar-worthy.
Claire Denis
French filmmaker Claire Denis is one of the most influential directors still working today, but it seems her movies might be regarded as too experimental for the Academy. Theyâre certainly missing out, though, because in her decades-long career, sheâs created timeless stories that stay with you long after the screen cuts to black.
From 1999âs Beau Travail, which is widely regarded as one of the best movies of its decade, to 2008âs critical hit 35 Shots of Rum, Denisâs storytelling and filmmaking style are distinct, captivating, and incredibly powerful.
In more recent years, Denis has directed indie favorites such as High Life, Let the Sunshine In, and Both Sides of the Blade.

Why Do These Tudor-Era Portraits of Anne Boleyn and Elizabeth I Look So Strikingly Similar?
The artist behind the works may have used Elizabeth’s likeness as a template in other royal portraits to visually emphasize her resemblance to previous monarchs and reinforce her status as the legitimate Tudor heir
A new exhibition at Anne Boleyn’s childhood home, Hever Castle, seeks to answer a question that has long captivated Tudor enthusiasts: What did the doomed queen actually look like?
Described by an ambassador as “not one of the handsomest women in the world,” with a “swarthy complexion, long neck, wide mouth” and striking black eyes, Anne—the second wife of the Tudor king Henry VIII—appears in only a few surviving near-contemporary portraits. These likenesses, however, are quite different from each other.
The most well-known image of Anne, a late 16th-century painting housed at the National Portrait Gallery (NPG) in London, depicts her with deep-set eyes, dark brown hair and a rather narrow face. A sketch of Anne that was drawn from life by court painter Hans Holbein the Younger in the 1530s, meanwhile, shows the queen with red or auburn hair and a rounder face. This lighter hair color also makes an appearance in a fairly unflattering portrait of Anne that dates to between 1597 and 1618.
Discrepancies in portrayals of Anne, who was beheaded on false charges of adultery and treason in 1536, stem in part from the circumstances of her death. Eager to enjoy marital bliss with his third wife, Jane Seymour, whom he wed just 11 days after Anne’s execution, Henry ordered the destruction of many reminders of his disgraced second wife, including portraits of her and decorations inside his palaces.
The Holbein sketch and a damaged medal held by the British Museum are two of the only likenesses of Anne known to date to her lifetime. (The Hever Castle show, titled “Capturing a Queen: The Image of Anne Boleyn,” will feature a previously unknown contemporary image of the queen, but details have yet to be released.) Other portraits were created posthumously, in some cases based on contemporary likenesses that are now lost.
The exhibition’s curators are particularly interested in the NPG painting, which is one of those posthumous portraits. While it doesn’t entirely align with other portrayals of Anne, it does bear a striking resemblance to three royal portraits painted in the late 16th and early 17th centuries, around the time of the reign of her daughter, Elizabeth I. The works in question depict Elizabeth; her older half-sister, Mary I; and her paternal great-grandfather, Edward IV.
These similarities aren’t simply a coincidence, says Owen Emmerson, an assistant curator at Hever Castle whose research forms the basis of the exhibition and an accompanying book (co-authored by fellow curator Kate McCaffrey) of the same name. According to a technical analysis performed by Lawrence Hendra, an art historian at Philip Mould & Company, all four portraits were painted by the same artist. They also feature “the same underlying facial geometry,” even though not all the sitters were genetically related, Emmerson tells Smithsonian magazine. (Anne is the outlier here, as she was only linked to Mary and Edward through her marriage to Henry.)
“The shared facial structure cannot reasonably be explained as biological likeness or casual copying,” Emmerson says. Instead, he argues that the anonymous artist based the portraits of Anne, Mary and Edward on an established “face pattern” of the then-queen, Elizabeth. Always conscious of her public persona, Elizabeth rarely sat for portraits; instead, she ordered artists to base their likenesses of her on a preapproved template designed to project a specific image of youthful beauty.
Fun facts: A royal decree to ban unflattering portraiture
- Toward the beginning of Elizabeth’s reign, the queen’s principal adviser, William Cecil, declared that none of the painters who’d created portraits of her thus far “hath sufficiently expressed the natural representation of Her Majesty’s person, favor or grace.”
- To address this issue, the crown banned new drawings, paintings and engravings of Elizabeth’s “personage or visage for a time,” until a worthy face pattern could be created and circulated for other artists to use as a model.
“It’s one artist doing a series of portraits of monarchs and putting on the face of the reigning queen, Elizabeth, to show a legitimate and God-ordained line of succession,” Emmerson tells the London Times’ Richard Brooks. Speaking with Smithsonian, he adds, “This was Elizabeth’s way of visually demonstrating that she was the legitimate Tudor heir”—an ever-present concern for the queen, who faced repeated challenges over her right to the throne.
Emmerson isn’t the first scholar to notice the similarities between the NPG painting of Anne and certain portraits of Elizabeth. In a 2010 blog post, historian Claire Ridgway argued that the NPG portrait was based on a circa 1590 depiction of Elizabeth by Marcus Gheeraerts the Younger, though she also acknowledged the possibility that Elizabeth simply “looked more and more like her mother as she grew older.” In a series of blog posts published between 2012 and 2022, historian Sylvia Barbara Soberton compared the NPG likeness to the same painting of Elizabeth now highlighted by Emmerson, the so-called Compton Verney portrait.
More recently, in her 2025 book, Secrets of the Tudor Portraits, Soberton argued that “a closer look” at the paintings of Anne and Elizabeth revealed more than “a natural likeness between the mother and daughter. … Compared side by side, it becomes evident that the unknown artist used almost identical face patterns in both paintings.”
Soberton’s interpretation contradicts the NPG’s official description of Anne’s portrait, which suggests the work is “probably based on a contemporary portrait” that no longer survives. “The most iconic painting of Anne turns out to have had nothing in common with her real appearance and more to do with how she was imagined by the Elizabethan audience,” Soberton wrote in Secrets of the Tudor Portraits. As the historian tells Smithsonian, the NPG painting is likely the product of “Elizabethan propaganda rather than a copy of the lost original.”
According to Emmerson, the four portraits highlighted by his analysis are situated in a specific moment during Elizabeth’s 45-year reign: the 1580s, when the Tudor queen’s “legitimacy, succession and ancestry were under renewed pressure,” as he explains to Smithsonian. A Protestant queen with a somewhat tenuous claim to the throne (she’d been declared a bastard following her mother’s execution), Elizabeth faced multiple threats to her authority around this time.
The pope excommunicated Elizabeth in 1570, condemning her as a “pretended queen … and the servant of crime.” A 1585 tract by an English Catholic accused her of being the product of an “incestuous marriage.” In the 1580s alone, Elizabeth’s spies foiled two separate plots to replace her with her Catholic cousin Mary, Queen of Scots.
“The pope’s given license to her subjects to challenge and overthrow her, and it’s compounded by the fact that she’s no longer of child-bearing age, she’s unmarried … so she cannot look to the future to promote her legitimacy,” Emmerson tells the Independent’s Harry Cockburn. Instead, he adds, Elizabeth sought to “promote her legitimacy by looking to the past to try and solidify her claim to the throne.”
The mirrored faces in the portraits of Elizabeth and her relatives represent “a conscious visual strategy that projected dynastic continuity and reinforced legitimacy through resemblance,” Emmerson explains to Smithsonian. As Hendra, the art historian who determined that the four works were painted by the same hand, tells the Times, the portraits were “probably [from] a workshop from the end of the 16th century, going into the early 17th, which appears to have a niche producing posthumous portraits of English kings and queens.”
Although the NPG portrait of Anne offers few answers to the question of her true appearance, it serves as “a valuable document of how Elizabeth’s regime understood and deployed the power of visual ancestry,” Emmerson tells Smithsonian. For those still curious about what Anne looked like, the Hever Castle exhibition will bring together more than 30 likenesses of her, displayed according to the eras in which they were created. Interestingly, Emmerson says to NPR’s Ailsa Chang, the more recent portraits tend to be “a lot more beautiful than the contemporary likenesses,” perhaps anticipating Anne’s depiction in popular media like “The Tudors” and The Other Boleyn Girl as a raven-haired seductress.
“We will be exploring why there is such a desire to capture Anne’s physical appearance, and asking our visitors if it even really mattered what Anne might have looked like,” says McCaffrey, the curator and co-author of Capturing a Queen, in a statement. “She was far more famed for her charisma, wit and intelligence.”
“Capturing a Queen: The Image of Anne Boleyn” will be on view at Hever Castle & Gardens in Hever, England, from February 11, 2026, to January 1, 2027.

A Little Boy’s Library Book Was Due in 1989. Thirty-Six Years Later, He Realized His Parents Had Never Returned It
After finding “Harry and the Dirty Dog” at his dad’s home in Greece, Dimitris Economou brought it back to the library in Virginia where his family had checked it out more than three decades earlier
Thirty-six years after it was checked out, a copy of Gene Zion’s Harry the Dirty Dog made its way back to the Chantilly Regional Library in Virginia.
Dimitris Economou found the book while visiting his parents in Greece and looking for something to read to his 7-year-old son.
“As we got to the end, I realized it was a library book,” Economou tells Northern Virginia magazine’s Michele Kettner. “I felt like I had to return it. … It just felt like the right thing to do.”
Published in 1956, the book tells the story of Harry, a dog who runs away from home to avoid taking a bath. Throughout his adventures, Harry gets quite dirty, and when he finally returns home, he is unrecognizable—until he finally takes a bath, that is.
According to a Facebook post from the public library system, Economou’s copy of the book was due on November 6, 1989, when he was 5. Harry the Dirty Dog spent the next three and a half decades traveling the world.
Economou’s parents were diplomats based in Washington, D.C. at the time the book was checked out. After spending the next seven years in Virginia, the family moved to Greece. Economou’s father took the book with him as he moved to Syria, Japan and the Netherlands, before eventually returning to Greece.
Economou, who traveled to northern Virginia during the holidays, decided to return the book while he was in town. He tells the Washington Post’s Maggie Penman that though the library stopped charging late fees a few years back, he would have happily paid a fine in support.
Quick facts: The largest library book fine ever paid
- In 2002, Emily Canellos-Simms returned a book that was nearly 50 years overdue to a library in Illinois.
- She wrote a check for $345.14, which is the world’s largest fee for an overdue book, according to Guinness World Records.
Ingrid Bowers, the branch manager at the library, was working when Economou came by to drop off the book.
“People really care about library books, and most people really care about getting them back. And this kind of proves it, that they really cared about getting the book back to us,” she tells the Washington Post.
While Harry the Dirty Dog’s global adventure lasted 36 years, some library books have been returned after much longer.
Last June, a copy of Your Child, His Family, and Friends by psychologist Frances Bruce Strain was returned to the San Antonio Public Library after nearly 82 years. The book had been borrowed from the library back in 1943.
In 2024, Walter Scott’s Ivanhoe made its way back to the Poudre River Public Library District 105 years past its due date. Luckily for the borrower, this library had also stopped enforcing late fees, which would have come out to about $14,000 when adjusting for inflation.
If 105 years isn’t long enough, a German text that was checked out around 1667 or 1668 was returned to the University of Cambridge’s Sidney Sussex College in 1956, nearly 300 years later.

Strange, Shovel-Tusked Elephants Puzzled Paleontologists, Until Experts Took a Closer Look at Their Teeth
The animals’ extended lower jaws were seemingly made for scooping, but research over the past few decades has found they could do a lot more than initially expected
The bones belonged to a prehistoric elephant, that much was certain, but they came from a species unlike any documented before. Paleontologists had uncovered a rib and single toe, alongside a nearly perfect—and truly unusual—jaw. While the joined mandibles looked like those of other fossil elephants at the molars, the lower jaw was ludicrously extended into a shovel-shaped tip with two long tusks. No jaw like it had ever been seen.
When paleontologist Erwin Barbour wrote a preliminary announcement of the bones’ discovery in the summer of 1927, he struggled to imagine how the beast had used its strange-looking tusks. Dubbing the animal Amebelodon fricki, Barbour couldn’t get over that shovel-like jaw.
“Can it be that this extraordinary mandible was used in dragging out freshwater seaweed or in digging up pond lilies, cattails, reeds and the like?” he wrote. Then again, the jaws seemed to pinch in the middle in a way that would have made them more vulnerable to bending and breaking. “The great leverage as well as the apparent structural weakness must be taken into account,” he added, speculating that “possibly the trunk was wound around this unique shovel-jaw to give it muscular reinforcement.”
Amebelodon was an oddball, a fossil elephant that did not fit in with the others. But the animal was not the only one of its kind. The year after Barbour named Amebelodon, Russian paleontologist Alexey Borissiak published a paper on a similar animal found in the southern part of his country and named it Platybelodon danovi. This new form had an even more scooplike jaw than Amebelodon did—and a later paper included a photo of the jaw next to a shovel to drive home the point.
Associating form with function made sense at the time, says Georgia Southern University paleontologist Kathlyn Smith. “If the form is a shovel, it’s a pretty logical hypothesis it would be used as such,” she says.
So early 20th-century paleontologists tried to imagine what sort of environment a shoveling jaw would work in. Thinking that habitats with soft sediment and lots of plants would make the most sense, they envisioned the fossil elephants there. Platybelodon, in particular, was assumed to inhabit the shores of silt-bottomed lakes, where it could scoop water lilies and other plants, its shovel jaws overlain by a flat, wormlike trunk.
Little by little, more shovel-jawed elephants tumbled out of the ancient rock. Amebelodon and Platybelodon turned out not to be offshoot oddities. Shovel-tuskers, as they came to be known among experts, had apparently been widespread, and more than a dozen species are now recognized from northern Africa, Europe, Asia and North America, found in rock layers 5 million to 23 million years old.
For decades after their initial discovery, the lifestyle of shovel tuskers seemed obvious. But now, with paper after paper, paleontologists have come to realize that shovel-shaped tusks were useful for a much broader range of behaviors than experts initially thought.
“Given the variety of species, and the variations in shovel shape, we should expect them to be using them for different tasks,” Smith says.
Re-examining the shovels
Paleontologist W. David Lambert questioned the shovel story in 1992 based on the wear and tear of the elephants’ teeth. When mammals feed, their food tends to scrape away enamel in telltale patterns, so what an animal was eating before death is often recorded in the teeth as microscopic scratches. Examining the tooth wear of Amebelodon, Platybelodon and a related animal named Torynobelodon, Lambert concluded that Amebelodon had used its jaws to feed in a range of ways, from scooping to scraping, while the other two had likely used their broad, square tusks to cut tough vegetation.
Fun facts: Elephant tusks
- Elephant tusks are simply elongated incisor teeth made primarily of dentine, the material just under the enamel of a tooth.
- Prehistoric elephants belonged to two main groups: two-tusked and four-tusked creatures. The shovel-tuskers, with their odd lower jaws, didn’t fall neatly into either group.
Lambert’s hypothesis was far from the last word. In recent years, paleontologists have uncovered more evidence that these odd proboscideans—members of the group of mammals that includes elephants and their relatives—were doing far more than shoveling. A 2022 study by Bay Path University paleontologist Gina Semprebon and her colleagues found that shovel-tuskers were not bound to soft sediment habitats full of sopping plants. The beasts were forest elephants that ate leaves and twigs, scraping and cutting their way through the Miocene salad bar.
The critical clues came from the remains of shovel-tusked elephants found in the rocks of Florida, which boasts its own species of Amebelodon as well as two other forms known as Konobelodon and Serbelodon. The key was to not get too focused on the scooplike shape of the lower jaw—the team instead studied wear on the upper tusks and molars as well as the peculiar lower jaw teeth.
Shovel-tuskers had a pair of conical upper tusks, like many of their mastodon relatives. And those upper tusks were not merely for show. Modern elephant species regularly use theirs as multitools, involved in everything from shoving contests to stripping bark from trees. The wear on the tusks and molars found among the shovel-tuskers indicated that they fell into the same pattern. The upper tusks of Amebelodon, Konobelodon and Serbelodon were used to scrape and cut, meaning these elephants, too, had a wide-ranging tusky toolkit.
Viewed under the microscope, the molar teeth of Amebelodon, Konobelodon and Serbelodon bore the same sort of pitting and scratches seen on modern African forest elephants. This signaled to Semprebon’s team that the shovel-tuskers were also browsers, likely living in habitats framed by trees, where the elephants plucked out succulent leaves, fruits and needle-filled branches.
Wear on the shovel tusks themselves also signaled flexible and variable behaviors. Amebelodon didn’t show any indication that it had been shoving its lower jaw into sediment. Barbour may have been right that the bone could not mechanically handle such an activity. Instead, the shovel teeth of Amebelodon showed wear patterns more consistent with bark-stripping and scraping. Konobelodon fossils, by contrast, did show some signs of digging, and Serbelodon teeth showed signs of both scooping and scraping.
The trunks of Platybelodon and relatives, too, are now thought to have been much like those of other elephants. “Based on the cutting edges of their tusks, their trunks were likely relatively long and tubular, like those of modern elephants, with the flexible proboscis helping hold vegetation against the tusks,” says Asier Larramendi, a paleontologist with the private research and illustration group Eofauna.
The mysterious fall of the shovel-tuskers
Shovel-tuskers were not oddballs restricted to a narrow way of life. The widespread elephants were well equipped to munch their way through ancient forests, pulling softer leaves off branches with their trunks and cutting through tougher plant foods with their teeth.
The multitool analogy makes sense for such elaborate structures as shovel tusks, Smith notes. The elongated jaws are energetically expensive for the animal’s body to grow and maintain, so multiple uses would be most efficient. “I’d be surprised if a shovel-tusker was only shoveling,” she notes, envisioning them “slicing, scraping, scooping, cutting and probably other things I can’t even think of.”
But if shovel tusks were so useful, why did this group of elephants disappear by five million years ago? That question is complicated. “Maybe the energetic expense of growing both upper tusks and lower tusks eventually outweighed the benefits as environments and climates changed,” Smith suggests; other forms of herbivores may have been better suited to the new conditions.
The spread of grasslands and fallback of forested habitats that began 20 million years ago might have had something to do with the disappearance of such successful elephants. “As grasslands expanded, feeding shifted away from the long lower jaw toward a more flexible trunk capable of coiling and grasping food,” Larramendi says. Shovel-shaped jaws for cutting and scraping tough objects like bark were less effective in prairie and savanna habitats with fewer trees. Meanwhile, trunks that could pull up clumps of grass, in addition to stripping leaves from branches, became more important over time. “Elephants relied increasingly on their trunks and less on elongated lower jaws, which eventually became shorter,” Larramendi says, the huge herbivores shifting to what best gathered the available plant food around them.
For now, no one really knows what led to the disappearance of the shovel-tuskers and other unusual elephant forms that lived before the age of human-caused extinction. It was a fundamentally different time on our planet, when multi-ton herbivores could drastically alter the habitats around them based on where they walked, how they fed and what trees they pushed over.
“Oh, to live in the heyday of proboscidean evolution,” Smith says, “when we had all these amazing, different forms.” The behemoths we know today are just the barest twigs on what was once a more abundant and unusual family tree, now held safe by the ancient rock.
